newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: Unified S.Africa tax, customs legislation tabled.
newsitem.headline: Unified S.Africa tax, customs legislation tabled.

text.p: The long-awaited legislation covering South Africa's merged inland revenue and customs and excise departments was tabled in parliament on Wednesday.

The South African Revenue Service (SARS) Bill provides the new service, formed on April 1 last year, with administrative autonomy but stops short of the full autonomy that some lobbyists might have wanted.
The Bill said that Cabinet had agreed that SARS should become an administratively autonomous revenue service with its own Act and "a certain level of control over its own resources."
SARS would fall outside public service controls over levels of pay and conditions of service but would remain subject to the basic values and principles governing public administration.

SARS' basic functions would be to collect all national taxes, duties and levies, flat-rate surcharges on the provinces, and other revenue and to advise the Minister of Finance on all revenue-related matters.
These functions would be performed under the policy control of, and subject to directives and guidelines issued by, the finance minister.
It would have a wide range of powers, such as the appointment of employees and buying of property, within the guidelines set by government.
"These powers will enable SARS to exercise better and a greater degree of control over its financial and human resources," the Bill said.
SARS would have an advisory board and its chief source of income would be money voted by parliament.
"Such income will be determined in accordance with estimates of income and expenditure and must make adequate provision for SARS to perform its functions," the Bill said.
